explanation:
The correct answer requires recognizing 8/12 simplifies to 2/3 (≈0.666), while 3/4 equals 0.75. To compare fractions, one would either convert to decimals or find equivalent fractions with a common denominator (e.g., 8/12 = 8/12 vs. 3/4 = 9/12). 

The student likely compared numerators directly (3 vs. 8) without equalizing denominators, concluding 3/4 was smaller due to the lower numerator. This stems from comparing absolute counts of shaded parts rather than their proportional relationships to the whole. 

The error directly aligns with the misconception of not using common denominators, as the student failed to adjust fractions to a comparable basis. It differs from the "larger denominators mean larger fractions" misconception because 3/4 has a smaller denominator than 8/12 but is actually larger. It also contrasts with "more shaded parts = larger fraction," as 8 shaded parts (in 8/12) represent a smaller value than 3 shaded parts (in 3/4).
